newsitem.title: GERMANY: FOCUS - BME/Reuters index shows German growth slowed.
newsitem.headline: FOCUS - BME/Reuters index shows German growth slowed.

text.p: Germany's manufacturing sector grew at a slower pace in July according to a BME/Reuters survey which analysts said indicates the Bundesbank will refrain from an interest rate rise unless the mark keeps weakening.
The BME/Reuters German Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) for July fell to a seasonally-adjusted 55.32 from 56.83 in June.

The index signalled strong growth because it remained well above 50 -- the level which reflects stagnation -- but the drop in July indicated a slight weakening in growth for the second month running, research group NTC Publications said.

The rates of expansion for new orders, output, prices and employment all weakened, NTC said. The PMI is modelled on the closely-watched U.S. National Association of Purchasing Management (NAPM) index.

Economists said the data showed Germany's economy remained split between a booming export sector driven by the weakness of the mark and a stagnating domestic sector restrained by high unemployment as firms kept shedding jobs in efficiency drives.
In such a scenario, the Bundesbank was only likely to raise interest rates if the mark continued to weaken to levels which would heighten the risk of importing inflation, analysts said.
"Further significant weakening of the Deutschmark is the precondition for any Bundesbank action on rates," David Brickman, European economist at Yamaichi in London, told Reuters Financial Television.

Financial markets have begun speculating that the Bundesbank may raise its main money market rate, the repo rate, as early as next week to stem the decline in the mark which has slid 20 percent against the dollar this year.
The dollar was trading around 1.85 marks on Friday.
"If the mark remains below the level of 1.85 marks the Bundesbank will not rock the boat and hike interest rates," said Ralph Sueppel, head of economic research at JP Morgan in Frankfurt.
"I think the case for an increase in the repo would be given if the dollar continues to rise at the same pace as it has over the past two months."
A dollar at 1.90 marks at the end of the Bundesbank's four-week summer recess on August 21 may prompt the bank to increase its 3.00 percent repo rate by 30 basis, Sueppel said.

The bank may then shift from a fixed-rate repo tender -- in which the Bundesbank sets the rate itself -- to a variable-rate system, in which the rate is the result of bank's bids for Bundesbank money.
The rate has been fixed at 3.00 percent since August 1996.
The employment index component of the BME/Reuters index fell to a seasonally-adjusted 48.11 from 49.26, reflecting continued job losses for the second month running.
"Firms remained reluctant to take on new staff, despite rising sales, preferring to further reduce costs through rationalisation of the workforce," NTC said.
Input prices rose for the sixth month running but the rate of increase was the slowest pace recorded since April.
New export orders rose to the highest level yet recorded by the survey, which began in April 1996 and showed the strongest monthly improvement in export order books to date, NTC said.
"Demand was reported to have risen in European, Asian and U.S. markets, driven largely by the increased competitiveness arising from the weaker exchange rate."
Separately, the Federal Statistics Office said German wholesale sales rose by one percent in real terms in the first six months. In June, wholesale sales rose 5.4 percent year-on-year.
Copyright in the BME/Reuters Purchasing Managers' INDEX is owned by Reuters Limited.

The index is based on a survey of 350 companies carried out exclusively for Reuters by research group NTC Publications Ltd in cooperation with the BME German Association for Materials Management, purchasing and Logistics.
